item.title: Covid: Supermarkets say shortages are not widespread
item.description: The Co-op says that supplies of soft drinks, beer and deodorant have been affected.

item.title: Major websites hit by global outage
item.description: Dozens of popular websites have been knocked offline.

item.title: Croydon tram crash: Passengers accidentally killed, jury finds
item.description: Seven people died when the tram tipped over and spun off the track in Croydon in November 2016.

item.title: Tommy Robinson loses Jamal Hijazi libel case
item.description: The High Court orders the anti-Islam activist to pay a teenage refugee £100,000 in damages.

item.title: Post Office scandal: Postmasters to get up to £100,000
item.description: Subpostmasters wrongly convicted of offences during an IT scandal are to receive interim compensation.

item.title: Covid-19: Shops try to ease pingdemic fears and record cases for adults in their 20s
item.description: Five things you need to know about the coronavirus pandemic this Thursday evening.

item.title: Covid cases at record levels for 20 to 29-year-olds
item.description: Everyone in this age group should be cautious when socialising, officials say, and get two jabs.

item.title: Olympics opening ceremony director sacked for Holocaust joke
item.description: The decision to remove Kentaro Kobayashi comes a day before the opening show is due to be held.

item.title: Gary Lineker to host new ITV gameshow, Sitting on a Fortune
item.description: The MOTD presenter will now also front Sitting on a Fortune, where contestants can win £100,000.

item.title: California sues Activision Blizzard over alleged harassment
item.description: One of the world's largest gaming companies is accused of endemic discrimination and harassment.

item.title: Michael Jackson super fan among those sanctioned by UK
item.description: A vice-president of Equatorial Guinea is among five people to receive UK "anti-corruption" sanctions.

item.title: Dawn Butler thrown out of Commons for PM lie accusation
item.description: Dawn Butler breaks parliamentary rules by accusing Boris Johnson of lying.

item.title: Tokyo Olympics: I beat an Olympian...when I was younger
item.description: Radio 1 Newsbeat speaks to people who can boast they once beat some of the current Team GB.

item.title: Halima Aden and Tommy Hilfiger: ‘It’s not just about diverse catwalks’
item.description: The world’s first hijab-wearing supermodel talks to fashion designer Tommy Hilfiger about why she quit the industry.

item.title: John Coates: Australian Olympic boss in awkward 'mansplaining' row
item.description: In an awkward exchange, John Coates ordered politician Annastacia Palaszczuk to attend the Olympics.

item.title: Tokyo 2020: Hend Zaza, 12, is youngest athlete at Olympics
item.description: Hend Zaza from Syria reveals her inspiration for getting into table tennis at such a young age.

item.title: Hamlet: Sir Ian McKellen's age-blind prince divides critics
item.description: The reviews are in for the veteran's re-working of the classic Shakespeare play.

item.title: I survived Norway's worst terror attack
item.description: Lisa Husby recalls hiding in fear as far-right extremist Anders Breivik went on a killing spree in 2011.

item.title: The jungle-trekking Covid vaccinators helping to protect remote Indian villages.
item.description: Latgam Singpu and his team use rope bridges, school buses and incentives to reach remote villages.

item.title: Tokyo 2020: Travelling to an Olympic Games like no other
item.description: The BBC's Mariko Oi reflects on her personal experience of covering the Games during a global pandemic.

item.title: Bradley Lowery: Building a legacy for the Sunderland fan
item.description: Bradley's mother Gemma explains how her charity is building a holiday home for children with illnesses.

item.title: Europe floods: 'I have an axe beside my bed'
item.description: Marion Wenzel showed the BBC around her flood-wrecked house in Ahrweiler, Germany.

item.title: 'I thought rape isn't something that happens to men'
item.description: Support charities say male victims of sexual assault sometimes feel their experiences don't count.

item.title: Lone women in Covid quarantine hotels to get female guards
item.description: The government is responding to continuing complaints of sexual harassment in hotel quarantine.

item.title: Zoomtown-on-Sea? The lure of a new life on the coast
item.description: Remote working meant the Lancaster family could live anywhere - they found their sea view in Scarborough.

item.title: Eating disorders: The terrible impact of the pandemic on the young
item.description: Admissions soared during the pandemic, and NHS bosses warn they are running out of beds.

item.title: Post Office scandal: What the Horizon saga is all about
item.description: The background to the cases of sub-postmasters whose convictions were based on evidence from faulty IT.

item.title: Anne-Marie: I've always loved the idea of revenge
item.description: The pop star on beating anxiety, growing bored of her biggest song, and her revenge fantasies.

item.title: Covid: Where and why is the US vaccine rollout slowing down?
item.description: Vaccinations in the US are slowing as infections rise - we've looked at where and why this is happening.

item.title: Nottingham maternity scandal: 'The pain never goes away'
item.description: More than 20 families demand a completely independent inquiry into an NHS trust's failing maternity services.

item.title: Soldier statue reignites Spanish row over fascism
item.description: Spain's legionnaires symbolised fascism, but Madrid may soon have a statue honouring them.

item.title: How global conferences are using tech to stay in business
item.description: Moving events online kept the industry going during the pandemic and now they're here to stay.

item.title: Benin Bronzes: Nigeria dispute jeopardises return of artefacts
item.description: Several museums in Europe have talked of returning the looted artefacts - but where will they be housed in Nigeria?

item.title: Brexit: What's the Northern Ireland Protocol?
item.description: Urgent changes to the post-Brexit Northern Ireland Protocol have been called for by the UK government.

item.title: Australia and NZ pull out of Rugby League World Cup
item.description: Australia and New Zealand pull out of the Rugby League World Cup because of "player welfare and safety concerns" related to the Covid-19 pandemic.

item.title: Tokyo 2020 men's football: Richarlison inspires Brazil, Spain held by Egypt, Wood makes history for NZ
item.description: Richarlison's first-half hat-trick inspires Brazil to a 4-2 win over Germany despite a second-half wobble, as Spain are held by Egypt.

item.title: F1 teams could face penalties if they visit race stewards without invitation
item.description: Formula 1 teams are warned they could face penalties if they visit race stewards without an invitation.

item.title: The first Test - readers' Lions XV and the key head to heads
item.description: BBC Sport reveals its readers' XV, which exposes some key head-to-head battles for Saturday's South Africa Test.

item.title: The Hundred opener breaks TV and crowd records
item.description: The Hundred's opening match, Oval Invincibles v Manchester Originals, breaks TV audience record

item.title: Tokyo Olympics: Dina Asher-Smith opens up on body image & tackling racism in sport
item.description: Dina Asher-Smith opens up about life on and off the track with friend and Radio 1 DJ Clara Amfo.

item.title: Tokyo Olympics: Brazil's Richarlison scores first-half hat-trick against Germany
item.description: Everton's Richarlison scores a first-half hat-trick for Brazil to make it 3-0 in their opening match against Germany at the Tokyo Olympics.

item.title: Care homes worst hit by Covid – search the data
item.description: Figures from Care Quality Commission lay out the pandemic's 'devastating impact' on care homes in England.

item.title: Covid: Who has to self-isolate and what if I'm fully vaccinated?
item.description: There has been confusion about who needs to self-isolate and which workers might be able to avoid it.

item.title: Covid rules from 19 July: What has changed?
item.description: Major changes to lockdown rules have taken effect in England and Scotland, but some restrictions remain.

item.title: Covid: When will I get the vaccine?
item.description: Vaccine experts recommend that a limited group of children should be offered Covid jabs ahead of winter.

item.title: Covid symptoms: Is it a cold or coronavirus?
item.description: With similar symptoms, deciding whether or not you need to get tested for coronavirus can be tricky.

item.title: Covid-19 in the UK: How many coronavirus cases are there in my area?
item.description: Explore the data on coronavirus in the UK and find out how many cases there are in your area.

item.title: Tokyo Olympic Games: When are they and will they go ahead despite Covid?
item.description: The Tokyo Summer Olympics begin formally on Friday, despite a surge in Covid cases in Japan.

item.title: Coronavirus: How does the NHS test-and-trace system and app work?
item.description: The contact tracing app could be changed to make it less sensitive, so it sends fewer alerts.

item.title: 'Covid passports': How can the NHS Covid Pass prove I've had both jabs?
item.description: Clubbers and people attending mass events in England will have to prove they've had both Covid jabs.

item.title: Beta coronavirus variant: What is the risk?
item.description: There are fears that this version of coronavirus, first identified in South Africa, is

item.title: Covid: What do under-30s need to know about the vaccine?
item.description: All over-18s can now get the Covid jab, but the government has criticised take-up among young people.

item.title: What are the rules for travelling to green, amber and red list countries?
item.description: Fully jabbed adults don't have to self-isolate after visiting amber-list countries - except France.

item.title: Which children are being vaccinated and why?
item.description: Hundreds of thousands of children at higher risk from coronavirus infection will be offered a Covid vaccine in the UK.

item.title: Long Covid: What is it and what are the symptoms?
item.description: New research links as many as 200 different symptoms to the condition.

item.title: What are the rules and guidance for face masks and coverings from 19 July?
item.description: Masks are no longer compulsory in England, but remain necessary in Scotland and Wales.

item.title: What are the travel rules for Spain, Portugal, Malta and other holiday hotspots?
item.description: What you need to know about going to Portugal, Spain, Greece, France, Malta, Italy and Turkey.

item.title: Covid: Why is social distancing coming to an end?
item.description: Social distancing rules are changing across the UK.

item.title: Covid-19: Five ways to avoid catching the virus indoors
item.description: As social distancing restrictions end in England and ease in Scotland, good ventilation remains vital.

item.title: The EU vaccine 'passport' and what it means for travel
item.description: An EU vaccine "passport" is being introduced, enabling holders to prove they have been jabbed.

item.title: Coronavirus cure: What progress are we making on treatments?
item.description: Medical teams around the world are learning which medicines work best against Covid.

item.title: Tokyo 2020: Olympic men's football players to watch
item.description: Here is the lowdown on the biggest names and brightest stars looking to shine this summer in the men's Olympic football tournament.

item.title: Tokyo Olympics: Katie Archibald on her gold medal dreams & pressure
item.description: Cyclist Katie Archibald tells BBC Sport about her dreams of another gold medal and the pressure of helping Laura Kenny become Britain's best.

item.title: Tokyo 2020: Top 10 days for Team GB at the Olympics
item.description: BBC Sport selects the top 10 unmissable days for Team GB fans at the Tokyo 2020 Olympics.

item.title: Tokyo Olympics: How quiet rebel Naomi Osaka is changing Japan
item.description: Naomi Osaka's relationship with Japan has not always been easy, but change rarely is. How the face of the Games is changing the host nation.

item.title: Tokyo Olympics: Day-by-day guide to the key events, big stars and British medal hopes
item.description: Want to know what's happening when in Tokyo? Check out our comprehensive guide to all the action in Japan.

item.title: Tokyo Olympics: Projected medal table, Team GB medallists and international stars to watch
item.description: Data company Gracenote forecasts the Tokyo 2020 medal table, Team GB medallists and the international stars to watch.

item.title: Tokyo Olympics: Tom Daley on triumph, trauma and his likely last shot at gold
item.description: The 'baby' of Beijing has become a father, a husband and an LGBTQ+ spokesperson. Tom Daley has perhaps one final shot at Olympic gold.

item.title: Tokyo Olympics: What to expect in the women's football tournament
item.description: The Olympic Games are almost here so what can we expect at the women's football tournament?

item.title: What are the new sports at the Tokyo Olympic Games?
item.description: With 34 new events in total added to the Tokyo Olympic programme, BBC Sport takes a look at what's new.

item.title: Cocaine in the UK: The DJ and friends helping addicts beat their 'beasts'
item.description: More people in the UK are taking cocaine. A DJ and ex-addict in Liverpool is helping them stop.

item.title: 'Jurassic Pompeii' yields thousands of 'squiggly wiggly' fossils
item.description: Scientists are excavating one of the most important Jurassic sites ever discovered in the UK.

item.title: Esther Dingley: Partner vows to keep searching for missing hiker
item.description: The partner of missing hiker Esther Dingley explains why he won't give up searching for her.

item.title: Under the skin of OnlyFans
item.description: A BBC investigation reveals concerns about how the site, known for porn, is structured and moderated.

item.title: The Broadway dancer whose lockdown business bloomed
item.description: When Covid closed New York theatres, dancer Robbie Fairchild started a business that put down roots.
